original: So the king asked, “Is there anyone left of Saul’s family to whom I can show the kindness of God?” Ziba answered, “There is still Jonathan’s son, who is lame in both feet.”
translation: King i askim, “Inap dispela famili bilong Saul i stap yet, na mi ken woksopim gutpela kina save bilong God long ol?” Ziba i ansa, “Pikinini bilong Jonathan i stap yet, tasol lega i kros long tupela fut.”

original: “Where is he?” replied the king. And Ziba said, “Indeed, he is in Lo-debar at the house of Machir son of Ammiel.”
translation: King i tok bek, "Em i stap we?" Na Ziba i tok, "Em i stap long Lo-debar, long haus bilong Machir, pikinini bilong Ammiel."

original: So King David had him brought from the house of Machir son of Ammiel in Lo-debar.
translation: King Davit i makim ol i bringim em from long haus bilong Makir sain bilong Amiel long Lo-debar.

original: And when Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, came to David, he fell facedown in reverence. Then David said, “Mephibosheth!” “I am your servant,” he replied.
translation: Na Mefiboset, pikinini bilong Jonatan, pikinini bilong Sau, i kam bek long Dauid, na ol i kilim gras na ol i go daun long graun long respek. Dauid tok, "Mefiboset!" "Mi wokman," em i bekim tok.

original: “Do not be afraid,” said David, “for surely I will show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan. I will restore to you all the land of your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table.”
translation: “Noken amamas long yu,” tok David, “tramua mi bai showim yu gutpela pasin long stap bilong tambu Jonathan. Mi bai bringim bek olgeta graun bilong tumbuna Saul i go long yu, na yu bai kaikai olsem tisa long mekim bikpela hap wantaim mi.”

original: Mephibosheth bowed down and said, “What is your servant, that you should show regard for a dead dog like me?”
translation: Mephibosheth i go daun klostu na tok, “Wokman bilong yu husat, dat yu givim respek long mi olsem dog we i dai finis?”

original: Then the king summoned Saul’s servant Ziba and said to him, “I have given to your master’s grandson all that belonged to Saul and to all his house.
translation: King i kolim Ziba, servant bilong Saul, na ol i tokim em, "Mi givim long gran son bilong masalai, olgeta samting bilong Saul na husat i stap long haus bilong en."

original: You and your sons and servants are to work the ground for him and bring in the harvest, so that your master’s grandson may have food to eat. But Mephibosheth, your master’s grandson, is always to eat at my table.” Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
translation: Yu na ol pikinini bilong yu na ol haus boi bilong yu mas wokim graun bilong em na kisim ka long taem bilong pikim ka, olesta granson bilong masta i kaikai. Tasol, Mephibosheth, granson bilong masta, em laik kaikai long tebol bilong mi olsem. Na Ziba i gat fiftenpela pikinini na twentipela haus boi.

original: And Ziba said to the king, “Your servant will do all that my lord the king has commanded.” So Mephibosheth ate at David’s table like one of the king’s own sons.
translation: Na Ziba i tokim king, “Husat i servs bai mi wokim ol samting we lori king i givim komando.” Na Mephibosheth i kaikai wantaim tebol bilong David olsem wanpela pikinini bilong king.

original: And Mephibosheth had a young son named Mica, and all who dwelt in the house of Ziba were servants of Mephibosheth.
translation: Na Mepiboset i gat pikinini man namel Mika, na olgeta i stap insait long haus bilong Ziba, ol i wokman bilong Mepiboset.

original: So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king’s table, and he was lame in both feet.
translation: Na Mepiboset i stap long Jirosalem, bikos em olsem i kaikai long tebol bilong king, na tupela lek bilong en i paul.

original: Some time later, the king of the Ammonites died and was succeeded by his son Hanun.
translation: Olgeta taim igo pinis, King bilong Ammonait pipel i dai pinis, na Hanun, Pikinini bilong em, i kam bihain im.

original: And David said, “I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.” So David sent some of his servants to console Hanun concerning his father. But when they arrived in the land of the Ammonites,
translation: Na Davit i tok, "Mi bai givim bekim long Hanun, pikinini bilong Nahash, olsem papa bilong em i givim bekim long mi." Na Davit i sendim wokman meri bilong en i go kisim hevi long Hanun, long taim papa bilong em i dai. Tasol, ol i kamap long kantri bilong Ammonait,

original: the princes of the Ammonites said to Hanun their lord, “Just because David has sent you comforters, do you really believe he is showing respect for your father? Has not David instead sent his servants to explore the city, spy it out, and overthrow it?”
translation: Pren namel long Ammonait i tokim Hanun ol bos bilong en, “Daudi i sendim man i kam confortim yu, em i mekim respek long papa bilong yu? Nogat, Daudi yet i sendim servan bilong en i go lusim taun, lukim i gut na tata?”

original: So Hanun took David’s servants, shaved off half of each man’s beard, cut off their garments at the hips, and sent them away.
translation: Na Hanun i kisim servis man bilong Daud, ol i kutim haf bilong beard bilong ol man, ol i katim klot bilong ol long hap, na ol i lusim ol i go.

original: When this was reported to David, he sent messengers to meet the men, since they had been thoroughly humiliated. The king told them, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return.”
translation: Taim ol i ripotim dispela stori long Davide, na em bingsolpela manmeri i go bekim ol man, ol i bin wail i kam strong. King i tokim ol, "Bai yupela i stap i go long Jeriko, na beards bilong yupela i kam bek, na tHEN yupela i ken kambak."

original: When the Ammonites realized that they had become a stench to David, they hired twenty thousand Aramean foot soldiers from Beth-rehob and Zoba, as well as a thousand men from the king of Maacah and twelve thousand men from Tob.
translation: Taim Ammonait i save ol i kamap na smel nogut long Daud, ol i kisim twenti tausen Aramean solja i go wakabaut long Bet-Rehob na Zoba, na tu tausen man long king bilong Maaka, na twelve tausen man long Tob.

original: On hearing this, David sent Joab and the entire army of mighty men.
translation: Long ol harim dispela, Dauid i sendim Joab na holim army bilong man ol i strong.

original: The Ammonites marched out and arrayed themselves for battle at the entrance of the city gate, while the Arameans of Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maacah were by themselves in the open country.
translation: Ammonait i go aut na katim planti long ples bilong fait long entris bilong gaten bilong taun, tasol Aramia bilong Soba na Rehob na man bilong Tob na Maaka ol i stap wankain long kantry op.

original: When Joab saw the battle lines before him and behind him, he selected some of the best men of Israel and arrayed them against the Arameans.
translation: Taim Joab i lukim lain bilong faet bifor em na bihain em, em i pilim sampela man strong na gutpela bilong Isrel na putim ol i go pas long Aramean.

original: And he placed the rest of the forces under the command of his brother Abishai, who arrayed them against the Ammonites.
translation: Na em putim namba olsem bilong solida bodi long komanda bilong brata Abishai, hu igo oraitim ol gen long enap long Ammonita.

original: “If the Arameans are too strong for me,” said Joab, “then you will come to my rescue. And if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come to your rescue.
translation: Sapos Aramen long strengim tumas long me, yu bai kam halivim mi. Na sapos Amonit long strongim tumas long yu, mi bai kam halivim yu.

original: Be strong and let us fight bravely for our people and for the cities of our God. May the LORD do what is good in His sight.”
translation: Strong i go, mipela paitim strong long pait olgeta long ol pipol bilong yumi na long taun bilong God bilong yumi. Mipela hop LORD bai wokim gud long ai bilong em.

original: So Joab and his troops advanced to fight the Arameans, who fled before him.
translation: Na Yoab wantaim ol solder bilong em i go bek, go fightim Aramia, na ol Aramia i ranawe bikos em.

original: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they too fled before Abishai, and they entered the city. So Joab returned from fighting against the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
translation: Taim Ammonait i si Aramean i ranawe, olgeta ranawe bifo Abisai, na ol i go insait long siti. Na Joab i kam bek gen long paitim Ammonait, i kam inap long Jerusalem.

original: When the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they regrouped.
translation: Taim Aramean i lukim ol i bin kilim ol long hap bilong Israel, ol i kam bek gen.

original: Hadadezer sent messengers to bring more Arameans from beyond the Euphrates, and they came to Helam with Shobach the commander of Hadadezer’s army leading them.
translation: Hadadeza sanem messenja i go kisim moa Aramean long biongo Yufratis, na ol i kam long Helam, wantaim Sobak komanda bilong armi bilong Hadadeza i lidim ol.

original: When this was reported to David, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, and went to Helam. Then the Arameans arrayed themselves against David and fought against him.
translation: Taim dispela i kam bek long Dafid, na em i bungim ol Isrel, em i go pas long Jordan, na em i go long Helam. Aramin i paitim yu yet long em, na ol i fait long em.

original: But the Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred charioteers and forty thousand foot soldiers. He also struck down Shobach the commander of their army, who died there.
translation: Ol Aramen i ranawe long Israel, na Daudi i kilim 700 man i drive kare na 40,000 man i go wakabaut. Na em i paitim Shobach komandan bilong ol, em i bos bilong army bilong ol, em i dai pinis long hap bilong em.

original: When all the kings who were subject to Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became subject to them. So the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites anymore.
translation: Wanpela taim ol kingly i kam lukim ol i bin kilim, ol i mekim pasi wantaim Isrel na i go daun long han bilong ol. Na Aramia i bikim afted long helpim Ammonita gen.

original: In the spring, at the time when kings march out to war, David sent out Joab and his servants with the whole army of Israel. They destroyed the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah, but David remained in Jerusalem.
translation: Long taim spring i kam, taim ol kingly bai go aut long pait, Daudi salim Joab na ol i wokman bilong em wantaim ol solja bilong Israel. Ol i bagarapim Ammonita, ol i beklong Raba, na Daudi i stap yet long Yerusalem.

original: One evening David got up from his bed and strolled around on the roof of the palace. And from the roof he saw a woman bathing—a very beautiful woman.
translation: Wanpela apinun Daavid i kam daun from bek na en, na i wokabaut ol i go long haf na haus bilong ki. Na long haf, i lukim meri wan, swit moa, i washim bodi.

original: So David sent and inquired about the woman, and he was told, “This is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.”
translation: Na Daudi i salim go askim, na ol i tokim em long meri, "Em Batsheba, duk bilong Eliam, meri bilong Uriah Hiti."

original: Then David sent messengers to get her, and when she came to him, he slept with her. (Now she had just purified herself from her uncleanness.) Then she returned home.
translation: Na David i sendim messija go bikim en i kam, na em i kam, David i go stap wantaim en. (Em i makim heself i klia from ol birua na dos bilong en, long lo bilong puripikeshon bilong en.) Na em i go bek long haus bilong en.

original: And the woman conceived and sent word to David, saying, “I am pregnant.”
translation: Meri i kamap na bai karim bebi, na ol i sendim tok long David, bikosi beli bilong me i karim.

original: At this, David sent orders to Joab: “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” So Joab sent him to David.
translation: Na Davide salim tok em i go long Joab: "Sindim mi Uriah Hiti." Na Joab bai sindim em i go long Davide.

original: When Uriah came to him, David asked how Joab and the troops were doing with the war.
translation: Wanpela taim Uriah i kam long em, Daud i askim olsem, Joab na ol solja i stap long pe wantaim war?

original: Then he said to Uriah, “Go down to your house and wash your feet.” So Uriah left the palace, and a gift from the king followed him.
translation: Em tokim Uriah, “Go daun i go haus bilong yu, wasim leg bilong yu.” Na Uriah lusim haus king, na givim samting nais bilong king i kam bihainim.

original: But Uriah slept at the door of the palace with all his master’s servants; he did not go down to his house.
translation: Bare Uria i slip long gate bilong haus kiya wantaim ol wokman bilong papa, na em i no go daun i go long haus bilong en.

original: And David was told, “Uriah did not go home.” “Haven’t you just arrived from a journey?” David asked Uriah. “Why didn’t you go home?”
translation: Ol i tokim David, "Uriah i no go bek long house." "Yu kam pinis nau from we bikpela turu, oghi?" David aria i askim Uriah. "Bai yu no go long house, wha?"

original: Uriah answered, “The ark and Israel and Judah are dwelling in tents, and my master Joab and his soldiers are camped in the open field. How can I go to my house to eat and drink and sleep with my wife? As surely as you live, and as your soul lives, I will not do such a thing!”
translation: Uriah i tokim, “Bokis bilong God, Isrel, na Judah ol i stap long tent, na bos bilong mipela Joab na solja bilong em ol i kambil long graun op. Yu go long haus bilong mi kaikai, dring, na slip wantaim meri bilong mi? Olsem yu stap, na olsem spirit bilong yu stap, mipela no inap duim ol samting olsem!”

original: “Stay here one more day,” David said to Uriah, “and tomorrow I will send you back.” So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.
translation: “Stap hia moa long wanpela de,” Daud i tokim Uriah, “na tumora mi bai sindaun yu bek.” Na Uriah i stap i go long Jerusalem olsem wanpela ples i gat bikpela significance that day na next day.

original: Then David invited Uriah to eat and drink with him, and he got Uriah drunk. And in the evening Uriah went out to lie down on his cot with his master’s servants, but he did not go home.
translation: Dauid i kam bekim Uriah kaikai na dring wantaim em, na i pulim Uriah long dring ol i masalai. Na long apinun Uriah i go aut na kalap long bet bilong sipervisa bilong masta, tasol i no go hom.

original: The next morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it with Uriah.
translation: Bikos em i go ap long moning nambawan dei, Daud i raitim leta long Joab na i sendim i go wantaim Uriah.

original: In the letter he wrote: “Put Uriah at the front of the fiercest battle; then withdraw from him, so that he may be struck down and killed.”
translation: Long letter em i raitim: “Putim Uriah long hap bilong bikpela gen na pait, kam bek gen long en, na bai em i pait na i dai.”

original: So as Joab besieged the city, he assigned Uriah to a place where he saw the strongest enemy soldiers.
translation: Olsem Joab i kam bekim siti, na em i givim Uriah wok long wanpela ples we i lukim solja i strong moa.

original: And when the men of the city came out and fought against Joab, some of David’s servants fell, and Uriah the Hittite also died.
translation: Taim ol man bilong siti i kam aut na ol i fait long Joab, sampela wokman bilong David i pundaun, na Uriah Hitti tu i dai.

original: Joab sent to David a full account of the battle
translation: Joab i josim ripot i kamap olsem long bikpela gen long David.

original: and instructed the messenger, “When you have finished giving the king all the details of the battle,
translation: Na em i givim tok tok long mesenga, “Wanpela taim yu kisim olgeta detel bilong pait i go daun na king i save,

original: if the king’s anger flares, he may ask you, ‘Why did you get so close to the city to fight? Did you not realize they would shoot from atop the wall?
translation: Sapos kaen i kirap strong, em bai askim yu, 'Oli stap long wanem yu go klostu long siti na pakim faet? Yu no save long ting olsem bai oli sutim olsem long antap long banis?

original: Who was the one to strike Abimelech son of Jerubbesheth? Was it not a woman who dropped an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez? Why did you get so close to the wall?’ If so, then you are to say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead as well.’”
translation: Husat i paitim Abimelech, pikinini bilong Jerubbesheth? Em ino wankain meri wanpela i ropim ston bilong en i go antap long en, na i kamdaun, na kilim em, na em i dai long Thebez? Wai yu go klos beside wal? Sapos olsem, orait, yu yet ken tokim ol, 'Servant bilong yu, Uriah Hittait, em i dai tu.'

original: So the messenger set out and reported to David all that Joab had sent him to say.
translation: Mesinja i go bek na i ripotim stori long Davit olgeta we Joab i salim em i kam tok.

original: The messenger said to David, “The men overpowered us and came out against us in the field, but we drove them back to the entrance of the gate.
translation: Mesinja i tokim Davide, “Ol man i strongim mipela na ol i kam aut gen long ples na go inap long mipela, tasol mipela i drihim ol i go bek long entris bilong gaten.”

original: Then the archers shot at your servants from the wall, and some of the king’s servants were killed. And your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead as well.”
translation: Ol archa i shootim yu long wal, na sampela long ol sarisa bilong king i bin dai. Na servant bilong yu Uriah Hiti i dai finis.

original: Then David told the messenger, “Say this to Joab: ‘Do not let this matter upset you, for the sword devours one as well as another. Strengthen your attack against the city and demolish it.’ Encourage him with these words.”
translation: Na Davidson i tokim mesenja, “Yu tokim Joab olsem: ‘No ken skulim bek long dispela samting, wantaim katim i kakai olsem na i go daun long sop. Katim i go het long ples, bagarapim em.’ Givim em kuraj long dispela tok.”

original: When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband was dead, she mourned for him.
translation: Meri bilong Uriah harim ol i kilim husban bilong em, na em i bin mekim sorim bikos em.

original: And when the time of mourning was over, David had her brought to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done was evil in the sight of the LORD.
translation: Na taim bilong sori i pinis, Davide em i kisim meri i go kam long haus bilong en, na em i stap wantaim em olsem meri bilong en, na em i karim bek boy bilong en. Tasol wok i bin mekim bilong Davide em i bagarap long ai bilong Bikpela.

original: Then the LORD sent Nathan to David, and when he arrived, he said, “There were two men in a certain city, one rich and the other poor.
translation: Bikpela i sendim Natan long David, na em i go kam, em i tok, “I gat tupela man long wanpela taun, wanpela i gutpela moni, na narapela i nogut moni.”

original: The rich man had a great number of sheep and cattle,
translation: Man i gat planti moni em i stap, na em i gat plenti sheep na bulmakau.

original: but the poor man had nothing except one small ewe lamb that he had bought. He raised it, and it grew up with him and his children. It shared his food and drank from his cup; it slept in his arms and was like a daughter to him.
translation: Man i no gat moni, i no gat narapela samting long en, tasol i gat wanpela liklik pik we em i bin baim. Em i raisim, na em i grow up wantaim em na ol pikinini bilong en. Ol i sharim kaikai long em, na em i dring long kap bilong em; em i slip long arm bilong em, na em i laik susa meri bilong em.

original: Now a traveler came to the rich man, who refrained from taking one of his own sheep or cattle to prepare for the traveler who had come to him. Instead, he took the poor man’s lamb and prepared it for his guest.”
translation: Nau wanpela man i warkabaut i kam klostu long man i gat plenti moni, na em i no tanim bek long tekem wanpela sheep bilong en o bulmakau long mekim preparison long man i warkabaut i kam. Long hap bilong, em i pilim wanpela ol pikinini sheep bilong man i no gat moni na i kukim ol i go long man i kam stap.

original: David burned with anger against the man and said to Nathan: “As surely as the LORD lives, the man who did this deserves to die!
translation: Daud i kirap long rausim bel long man nau, na em i tokim Natan: “Olsem LORD i stap, man i mekim dispela olsem i mas dai!

original: Because he has done this thing and has shown no pity, he must pay for the lamb four times over.”
translation: Bikos em wokim dispela na em i no givim kros, em bai pei foa taim moa long lamb.

original: Then Nathan said to David, “You are that man! This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
translation: Natan i tokim David olsem, "Yu em i man bilong dispela tok! Dispela em i tok: LORD, God bilong Israel, i tok olsem, 'Mi bin givim yu oli bilong spirit, na mi bin mekim yu king i go long Israel, na mi bin skulim yu long han bilong Saul.'"

original: I gave your master’s house to you and your master’s wives into your arms. I gave you the house of Israel and Judah, and if that was not enough, I would have given you even more.
translation: Mi givim haus bilong maser ol i go long yu, na meri bilong maser ol i go long arm bilong yu. Mi givim yu hus bilong Israel na Yuda, na sopas em i no inaf, bai mi givim yu sampela samting moa.

original: Why then have you despised the command of the LORD by doing evil in His sight? You put Uriah the Hittite to the sword and took his wife as your own, for you have slain him with the sword of the Ammonites.
translation: Olsem wanem yu kam dispela komando bilong LORD i go daun, wok olgets long ai bilong em? Yu kilim Uriah Hiti wantaim sord na yu tek meri bilong em i kam bilong yu, bikos yu kilim em wantaim sord bilong Ammonaitis.

original: Now, therefore, the sword will never depart from your house, because you have despised Me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your own.’
translation: Nau, olsem na, sop bai i no inap lusim haus bilong yu, bikos yu masalai mipela na yu kisim meri bilong Uriah Hiti, man i go wok long yu.

original: This is what the LORD says: ‘I will raise up adversity against you from your own house. Before your very eyes I will take your wives and give them to another, and he will lie with them in broad daylight.
translation: Dispela Bikpela i tok olsem: 'Mi bai bringim trabel long yu from hap bilong hous bilong yu. Long ai bilong yu, mi bai takeda meri bilong yu na givim ol long narapela man, na em bai sleep wantaim ol long taem bilong de.

original: You have acted in secret, but I will do this thing in broad daylight before all Israel.’”
translation: Yu wokim olgeta samting long sekrit, tasol mi bai mekim dispela wok long dei, san i birua, bihain ol Israel, ol pipol bilong God, olgeta manmeri bai si.

original: Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the LORD.” “The LORD has taken away your sin,” Nathan replied. “You will not die.
translation: Na David i tokim Nathan, "Mi go pinis long han bilong LORD." Nathan i bekim tok, "LORD i kisim sin bilong yu go we. Yu no ken dai."

original: Nevertheless, because by this deed you have shown utter contempt for the word of the LORD, the son born to you will surely die.”
translation: Nogat sem, stap long olgetting dispela wok, yu mas pinis mekim birua tru long tok bilong Jehovah, bai pikinini i kam long yu em bai dai tasol.

original: After Nathan had gone home, the LORD struck the child that Uriah’s wife had borne to David, and he became ill.
translation: Natan i go bek long haus bilong en, na LORD i kilim pikinini i bin kam long meri bilong Uriah we i bin givim nau long Daud, na pikinini i sik.

original: David pleaded with God for the boy. He fasted and went into his house and spent the night lying in sackcloth on the ground.
translation: Daud i kisim kot long Bikpela bilong boi. I mai painim ka na i go insait long haus bilong en, na i slip long graun, i katim apinun long sak klot.

original: The elders of his household stood beside him to help him up from the ground, but he was unwilling and would not eat anything with them.
translation: Ol bikpela husat i stap long hauslain bilong en, ol i stap besaidim em, helpim em i kam daunuan long graun, tasol em i no laik, em i no gat laik kaikai gen wantaim ol.

original: On the seventh day the child died. But David’s servants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, “Look, while the child was alive, we spoke to him, and he would not listen to us. So how can we tell him the child is dead? He may even harm himself.”
translation: Long nait bipka na de sekhen pikinini i dai pinis. Tasol wokman bilong Daud i bikpela tarawe long tokim em, ol i tok, "Em i lukim, wail pikinini i stap yet, mipela i toktok wantaim em, na em no ken harim mipela. Olsem wanem bai mipela tokim em pikinini i dai pinis? Em i mas kansel i bagarapim em yet."

original: When David saw that his servants were whispering to one another, he perceived that the child was dead. So he asked his servants, “Is the child dead?” “He is dead,” they replied.
translation: Daudi harim ol i stap toktok i go insait long husat, em i save olsem pikinini i dai pinis. Na em i askim servantram bilong en, "Pikinini i dai pinis?" Ol i givim ansa, "Em i dai pinis."

original: Then David got up from the ground, washed and anointed himself, changed his clothes, and went into the house of the LORD and worshiped. Then he went to his own house, and at his request they set food before him, and he ate.
translation: Na Dauid em i kam bek long graun, em i wasim skin na putim ol samting bilong en God long bodi bilong en, em i chanjim klos bilong en, na em i go insait long haus bilong LORD na wosipim. Na em i go long haus bilong en, na long ka bilong en, ol i salim ka bilong kukim na putim bifor em, na em i kai.

original: “What is this you have done?” his servants asked. “While the child was alive, you fasted and wept, but when he died, you got up and ate.”
translation: Wanem samting yu mekim? Servant i askim. Wail pikinini i stap, yu painim hangre na katim gris, tasol taim em i dai pinis, yu kirap na kaikai.

original: David answered, “While the child was alive, I fasted and wept, for I said, ‘Who knows? The LORD may be gracious to me and let him live.’
translation: Dauid i bekim tok, "Bai bikos pikinini i stap, mi kisim kaikai nok olsem prai bilong beten, na mi tarai, bikos mi tok, 'Husat save? Papa God bai givim meri long me na lusim em i stap.'"

original: But now that he is dead, why should I fast? Can I bring him back again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.”
translation: Bai nau em i dai pinis, walumi olsem wanem long mi? Inap mi kisim bek i kam bek gen? Bai mi go kamdaun long en, tasol em i no ken kam bek gen long me.

original: Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba, and he went to her and lay with her. So she gave birth to a son, and they named him Solomon. Now the LORD loved the child
translation: Na Daudi i kam bekim haus kilim tok bilong meri bilong en, Bathsheba, na em i go klostu long en na em i stap wantaim. Meri i karim bebé na i bonim man, na ol i givim nem bilong pikinini olsem Solomona. Na LORD i laikim dispela pikinini.

original: and sent word through Nathan the prophet to name him Jedidiah because the LORD loved him.
translation: Na God i sendim tok olsem long Natan propet, i mekim ol i givim nem bilong en Jedidia, bikos LORD i lakim em.

original: Meanwhile, Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured the royal fortress.
translation: Wanpela taim, Yoab i go fait long Raba bilong Pipol Ammon na i kisim haus bilong king.

original: Then Joab sent messengers to David to say, “I have fought against Rabbah and have captured the water supply of the city.
translation: Yoab salim mesijer long Davit ol i tok, "Mi kam painim Raba na winim, mipela kisim wara bilong siti, em i laif bilong ol pipol long siti".

original: Now, therefore, assemble the rest of the troops, lay siege to the city, and capture it. Otherwise I will capture the city, and it will be named after me.”
translation: Nau, olsem na, kam bek long ol narapela solja, kisim i go long klostu long taun, na taitim em. Ina bai mi yet taitim taun, na givim nem long taun bilong man, neming long nem bilong mi.

original: So David assembled all the troops and went to Rabbah; and he fought against it and captured it.
translation: Na Daved i kamapim ol soldia yet, na em i go long Raba, na ol i fait long em, na ol i kisim em.

original: Then he took the crown from the head of their king. It weighed a talent of gold and was set with precious stones, and it was placed on David’s head. And David took a great amount of plunder from the city.
translation: Na em i kisim krown na putim i go daun long hed bilong king bilong ol. Krown ia i kaikai moa long wan talen bilong gol, na ston nogut tru i kamap bilong en, na em i go antap long hed bilong Dauid. Na Dauid i kukim planti lo bilong taun ia.

original: David brought out the people who were there and put them to work with saws, iron picks, and axes, and he made them work at the brick kilns. He did the same to all the Ammonite cities. Then David and all his troops returned to Jerusalem.
translation: Daud i kamautim ol pipol we i stap na i givim wok long ol: ais ol i katim diwai, pik bilong aisen, na akis, na i mekim ol wok long ples brick kilns. I mekim olsem long ol siti bilong Ammon. Na Daud wantaim ol solja bilong en i go bek gen long Jerusalem.

original: After some time, David’s son Amnon fell in love with Tamar, the beautiful sister of David’s son Absalom.
translation: Long taem igo pinis, Amon, pikinini man bilong Daveid, i kamapim lovette long Tama, susa nais bilong Absalom.

original: Amnon was sick with frustration over his sister Tamar, for she was a virgin, and it seemed implausible for him to do anything to her.
translation: Amnon em i sik wantaim bungim head long meri ia yet, Tamar, bikos em i meri ia yet, na i lukim olsem nogat ken tru long en tru long mekim wanpela samting long en.

original: Now Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah. Jonadab was a very shrewd man,
translation: Nau Amnon i gat wanpela poroman, em Jonadab, pikinini bilong brotha bilong Davit, Shimeah. Jonadab em i man bilong bikpela save.

original: so he asked Amnon, “Why are you, the son of the king, so depressed morning after morning? Won’t you tell me?” Amnon replied, “I am in love with Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.”
translation: Na em i askim Amnon, "Wai yu, pikinini bilong king, i bikim sorimi olsem moning na moning? Yu no ken tokim mi?" Amnon i tok, "Mi stap long lov wantaim Tamar, susa bilong brata bilong mi Absalom."

original: Jonadab told him, “Lie down on your bed and pretend you are ill. When your father comes to see you, say to him, ‘Please let my sister Tamar come and give me something to eat. Let her prepare it in my sight so I may watch her and eat it from her hand.’”
translation: Jonadab i tokim em, "Lay dun na balus bilong yu na pretem yu sik. Wanpela taim papa yu i kam lukim yu, tokim em olsem, 'Papa, mipela susa Tamar i kam na givim mi kaikai. Em i kukim long ai bilong mi, na mipela wachim em na kaikai wantaim han bilong em.'"

original: So Amnon lay down and feigned illness. When the king came to see him, Amnon said, “Please let my sister Tamar come and make a couple of cakes in my sight, so that I may eat from her hand.”
translation: Na Amnon i lid i go na mekim olsem em i sik. King i kam lukim em, Amnon i tok, "Ples long susa Tamar bilong mi i kam na mekim tupela ka yet long ai bilong mi, na bai mi kai pinis long han bilong em."

original: Then David sent word to Tamar at the palace: “Please go to the house of Amnon your brother and prepare a meal for him.”
translation: Na Daved i givim tok long Tamar long haus kiya: “Yu kam go long haus bilong Amnon brata yuu na preparim kaikai long em.”

original: So Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, who was lying down. She took some dough, kneaded it, made cakes in his sight, and baked them.
translation: Na Tamar i go long haus bilong brata Amnon, em i lusim i slip. Em i kisim sampela dok, em i wokim em i ken long ai bilong en, em i mekim kek long sinting bilong en, na em i kukim ol kek.

original: Then she brought the pan and set it down before him, but he refused to eat. “Send everyone away!” said Amnon. And everyone went out.
translation: Na meri bam bringim pan na raitim i go daun bifo em, tasol em i no laik kaikai. “Usim ol pipol i go was!” Amnon i tok. Na ol pipol i go aut.

original: Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food into the bedroom, so that I may eat it from your hand.” Tamar took the cakes she had made and went to her brother Amnon’s bedroom.
translation: Na Amnon i tokim Tamar, “Bringim kaek i go insait long rum blong slip, na mi bai kaikai long han blong yu.” Tamar i kisim kaek we i bin mekim na i go long rum blong brata, Amnon.

original: And when she had brought them to him to eat, he took hold of her and said, “Come lie with me, my sister!”
translation: Na em i bringim ol ka long en, em i kisim strong long em na i tok, 'Kam, susa, yumi go slip!'

original: “No, my brother!” she cried. “Do not humiliate me, for such a thing should never be done in Israel. Do not do this disgraceful thing!
translation: Nogat, brata! Em i krai. No ken mekim shame long me, olgeta samting olsem no ken hapen long Israel. Yu no ken mekim dispela kain pasal bilong shame, em i nogut tru!

original: Where could I ever take my shame? And you would be like one of the fools in Israel! Please speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.”
translation: Bai mi kisim sham bilong mi go we? Na yu bai wok olsem wanpela long ol i no save long Israel! Plis, tokim king, bikos em i no ken holim yu long me.

original: But Amnon refused to listen to her, and being stronger, he violated her and lay with her.
translation: Amnon i no givim ear long hap, na em i strongpela, nogat wanem, i bagarap meri, na i slep wantaim.

original: Then Amnon hated Tamar with such intensity that his hatred was greater than the love he previously had. “Get up!” he said to her. “Be gone!”
translation: Na Amnon i biruaim Tamar long streng olgeta, na hatred bilong en i bikpela moa long lovwe we em bin gat bifo. “Kam daun na!” em i tokim Tamar. “Go bek!”

original: “No,” she replied, “sending me away is worse than this great wrong you have already done to me!” But he refused to listen to her.
translation: “Nogat,” em i tok bek, “pusim me go em i wors na dispela bikpela wrong yu mekim long mi!” Tasol em i no lissen long tok bilong en.

original: Instead, he called to his attendant and said, “Throw this woman out and bolt the door behind her!”
translation: Em i singautim han i go long servant bilong en, tasol em i tokim olsem, “Putim meri ia long aus na klosim door bihain long em!”

original: So Amnon’s attendant threw her out and bolted the door behind her. Now Tamar was wearing a robe of many colors, because this is what the king’s virgin daughters wore.
translation: Na husat i wokim wok bilong Amnon i rimpasim em long nambis na klosim diwai bikos em i no inap go bek gen. Na Tamar i wes ka bilong plenti kala, olsem kalture bilong king, bikos ol meri bilong king yet i wes olka stori bilong kantri.

original: And Tamar put ashes on her head and tore her robe. And putting her hand on her head, she went away crying bitterly.
translation: Na Tamar i pasim as bilong faia long hed bilong em, na i rausim skot bilong em. Na i putim han bilong en long hed bilong en, na i go na i krai olsem i sori tru.

original: Her brother Absalom said to her, “Has your brother Amnon been with you? Be quiet for now, my sister. He is your brother. Do not take this thing to heart.” So Tamar lived as a desolate woman in the house of her brother Absalom.
translation: Brata Absalom i tokim em, "Brata Amnon i go we? Kisim ka long stua nau, susa bilong mi. Em i brata bilong yu. No ken skulim dispela samting long het bilong yu." Na Tamar i stap olsem meri nogut, meri i no gat husban, i stap long haus bilong brata Absalom.

original: When King David heard all this, he was furious.
translation: Taim King Davide harim ol dispela, em i bekim strong.

original: And Absalom never said a word to Amnon, either good or bad, because he hated Amnon for disgracing his sister Tamar.
translation: Na Absalom em i no tokim wod yet long Amnon, nailen long stap gut na long stap olsem, bikos em i birua Amnon long meekim shame long susa bilong en, Tamar.

original: Two years later, when Absalom’s sheepshearers were at Baal-hazor near Ephraim, he invited all the sons of the king.
translation: Ta yu bihaen long tupela yia, wankain taem shepshearers bilong Absalom i stap long Baal-hazor klostu long Ephraim, emi kalim ol pikinini bilong king olgeta.

original: And he went to the king and said, “Your servant has just hired shearers. Will the king and his servants please come with me?”
translation: Em i go long king na em i tok, “Wokman bilong yu nau kamap haitman bai katim gris. King na ol servants bilong en, bai yu kam ples wantaim mi?”

original: “No, my son,” the king replied, “we should not all go, or we would be a burden to you.” Although Absalom urged him, he was not willing to go, but gave him his blessing.
translation: King i tokim pikinini, "Nogat yumi ol i go, oderwise mipela bai i wari long yu." Absalom i askim strongim em, tasol em i no bin wan go, na em i givim em birua.

original: “If not,” said Absalom, “please let my brother Amnon go with us.” “Why should he go with you?” the king asked.
translation: “Nogat tasol,” i tok olsem Absalom, “plis, let mi brotha Amnon i go wantaim mipela.” “Wai em i go wantaim yu?” king i askim.

original: But Absalom urged him, so the king sent Amnon and the rest of his sons.
translation: Absalom i tok strong long em, na papa bilong yumi i sendim Amnon na ol narapela pikinini bilong em.

original: Now Absalom had ordered his young men, “Watch Amnon until his heart is merry with wine, and when I order you to strike Amnon down, you are to kill him. Do not be afraid. Have I not commanded you? Be courageous and valiant!”
translation: Nau Absaloum i bin givim tok long ol yong man bilong en, “Wachim Amnon long taim em i kamap hapi na i drink win, na long taim mi tokim yu slip Amnon, yu mas kilim em. No ken kirap, mi bin givim tok long yu, kamap strong na birua!”

original: So Absalom’s young men did to Amnon just as Absalom had ordered. Then all the other sons of the king got up, and each one fled on his mule.
translation: Ol yong man bilong Absalom wokim long Amnon olsem nau Absalom i tokim ol. Na ol narapela pikinini bilong king em i go ap, na nen igat i ranawe long mule bilong en.

original: While they were on the way, a report reached David: “Absalom has struck down all the sons of the king; not one of them is left!”
translation: Wail ol i go long rot, ripot ikam long Daud: "Absalom im paitim ol pikinini bilong king; maski wan nogat i stap!"

original: Then the king stood up, tore his clothes, and lay down on the ground; and all his servants stood by with their clothes torn.
translation: King i stap up, i rausim klotes bilong en, na i lidown long graun; na ol servist bilong en i stap bikos, olgeta i rausim klotes bilong ol.

original: But Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, spoke up: “My lord must not think they have killed all the sons of the king, for only Amnon is dead. In fact, Absalom has planned this since the day Amnon violated his sister Tamar.
translation: Jonadab, pikinini bilong Simeah, brata bilong Daud, i tok bek: "Papa bilong yu no ken ting ol pikinini bilong king em ol i dai pinis, tasol Amnon em i dai pinis. Absalom i planim dispela long taim Amnon i bagarap susa bilong en Tamar.

original: So now, my lord the king, do not take to heart the report that all the sons of the king are dead. Only Amnon is dead.”
translation: Nau, papa bilong mipela king, no ken tasol long het ripot i kam inap long ol: ol pikinini bilong king i dai pinis. Amnon tasol i dai.

original: Meanwhile, Absalom had fled. When the young man standing watch looked up, he saw many people coming down the road west of him, along the side of the hill. And the watchman went and reported to the king, “I see men coming from the direction of Horonaim, along the side of the hill.”
translation: Na Absalom i ranawe nau. Yung man i stap long wach i luk up, na em i si planti man i kam doun long rot we i stap long sait bilong hil, long wes sai. Na wachman i go na em i toktok long king, "Mi si ol man i kam fromwei long Horonaim, long sait bilong hil."

original: So Jonadab said to the king, “Look, the sons of the king have arrived! It is just as your servant said.”
translation: Jonadab i tokim king, "Luke, pikinini bilong yu ol i kam! Em i olsem servant bilong yu i tok."

original: And as he finished speaking, the sons of the king came in, wailing loudly. Then the king and all his servants also wept very bitterly.
translation: Na em i tok pinis, pikinini bilong papa bilong ol i kam insait, kilang strong. King na ol wokman bilong en i karai i go het long moning.

original: Now Absalom fled and went to Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. But David mourned for his son every day.
translation: Nau Absalom i rim na i go, na i go kam bek long Talmai, pikinini bilong Ammihud, king bilong Geshur. Tasol David i bin sorry tru long pikinini bilong em, Absalom, bek long oldei.

original: After Absalom had fled and gone to Geshur, he stayed there three years.
translation: Absalom i ranawe na i go long Geshur, na i stap we long hap tripela yia.

original: And King David longed to go to Absalom, for he had been consoled over Amnon’s death.
translation: Na Bikpela Chief Davit i laik go long Absalom, wantaim ol i kamap strong gen bilong en long en, bekas em i kisim gutpela bilip long dai bilong Amnon.

original: Now Joab son of Zeruiah perceived that the king’s heart longed for Absalom.
translation: Nau Joab sussa Zeruiah i save olsem het bilong king i stilim strong long Absalom.

original: So Joab sent to Tekoa to bring a wise woman from there. He told her, “Please pretend to be a mourner; put on clothes for mourning and do not anoint yourself with oil. Act like a woman who has mourned for the dead a long time.
translation: Na Joab i salim go long Tekoa, kisim i kam meri strong long tingting. Em i tokim em, "Bihaim olsem samting i bin kamap long yu na yu sori, kisim klos bilong sori putim long body, no ken putim oil long body. Wok long olsem meri i bin sori wantaim man i dai pinis long taim.

original: Then go to the king and speak these words to him.” And Joab put the words in her mouth.
translation: Go long king na tokim dispela tok long em.” Na Joab putim tok long hus bilong meri.

original: When the woman from Tekoa went to the king, she fell facedown in homage and said, “Help me, O king!”
translation: Taim meri bilong Tekoa i go kasol long king, ol i pilai daun bungim-faced long givim respek na ol i tok, "Halivim mi, king!"

original: “What troubles you?” the king asked her. “Indeed,” she said, “I am a widow, for my husband is dead.
translation: “Wanem i wari long yu?” king i askim her. “Intri,” na em i tok, “Mi mere widou, husbant bilong mi i dai pinis.”

original: And your maidservant had two sons who were fighting in the field with no one to separate them, and one struck the other and killed him.
translation: Na meri bilong wok long haus mipela i gat tu olpela pikinini man, ol i kaikai long plan, nogat narapela man bai sindaun long tupela, na wanpela bilong ol i kilim dead narapela wan.

original: Now the whole clan has risen up against your maidservant and said, ‘Hand over the one who struck down his brother, that we may put him to death for the life of the brother whom he killed. Then we will cut off the heir as well!’ So they would extinguish my one remaining ember by not preserving my husband’s name or posterity on the earth.”
translation: Nau ol clans i go antap long meri servist mi, ol i tok, 'Givim man i paitim brata bilong em, kilim man nau long laip bilong brata i kilim.' Na bai ol kisim ovasi heir bilong yumi tu. Ol i laik ausim embers bilong mi i stap, na ol i no save long nem bilong husband bilong mi, na generesen bilong en i stap long graun.

original: “Go home,” the king said to the woman, “and I will give orders on your behalf.”
translation: “Go long haus,” king i tokim meri, “na mi bai givim tok instruksin long namel bilong yu.”

original: But the woman of Tekoa said to the king, “My lord the king, may any blame be on me and on my father’s house, and may the king and his throne be guiltless.”
translation: Meri bilong Tekoa i tokim king, “King bilong mipela, balus bilong gilty bai i kam long mi na long haus bilong papa bilong mi, king na tron bilong en, ol i mas nogat gilty.”

original: “If anyone speaks to you,” said the king, “bring him to me, and he will not trouble you again!”
translation: “Papa bilong yumi olgeta i tokim ol,” em i tok, “I go tokim yu, kisim man i kam long me, na em no inap bagarapim yu gen!”

original: “Please,” she replied, “may the king invoke the LORD your God to prevent the avenger of blood from increasing the devastation, so that my son may not be destroyed!” “As surely as the LORD lives,” he vowed, “not a hair of your son’s head will fall to the ground.”
translation: “Na em tok bek,” ol i tok, “king i mas kisim Bikpela LORD God bilong yu, i no givim man bilong paitim bloo long kamap strong na bagarapim planti, son bilong mi no ken dai.” “Olsem Bikpela i stap,” em i tok strong, “hap bilong hed bilong pikinini bilong yu bai no ken bagarap, not a hair blong hed bilong yu bai fal daun long graun.”

original: Then the woman said, “Please, may your servant speak a word to my lord the king?” “Speak,” he replied.
translation: Meri i tok, "Papa bilong mipela, king, mipela i tokim wanpela toktok long yu?" Em i mekim bek, "Tokim!"

original: The woman asked, “Why have you devised a thing like this against the people of God? When the king says this, does he not convict himself, since he has not brought back his own banished son?
translation: Meri i askim, “Wai yu bin kamapim samting olsem long narapela hap bilong Pikinini bilong God?” Taim king i tok olsem, em i no katim aut yet im sel, long em i no bringim bekim pikinini bilong en i go we long taim?

original: For surely we will die and be like water poured out on the ground, which cannot be recovered. Yet God does not take away a life; but He devises ways that the banished one may not be cast out from Him.
translation: Sampela taim, yumi ol dai na yumi olsem wara i go daun long graun, i no inap kambak gen. Tasol God i no kilim laip, bai em i wokim wei olsem banisim man i no drivim i go, na i no rasim bek long em.

original: Now therefore, I have come to present this matter to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid. Your servant thought, ‘I will speak to the king. Perhaps he will grant the request of his maidservant.
translation: Nau olgeta, mi kam long tok ples bilong dispela matar long papa bilong mipela king, na em i kam bikos ol pipel i save me kirapim fear. Wokman bilong yu, em tok olsem, ‘Mi go tokim king, em inogat posibol bai em givim wanem samting we meri bilong em i laik.’

original: For the king will hear and deliver his maidservant from the hand of the man who would cut off both me and my son from God’s inheritance.’
translation: King bai harim na bai saveman meri bilong em long han bilong man i laik katim yumi two long inheritance bilong God.

original: And now your servant says, ‘May the word of my lord the king bring me rest, for my lord the king is able to discern good and evil, just like the angel of God. May the LORD your God be with you.’”
translation: Na nau servant bilong yu tok, ‘Tok bilong papa bilong yu king ina bringim mi givim ripos, wantaim papa bilong yu king i save harm na gupela, olsem angel bilong God. LORD God bilong yu i go wantaim yu.’”

original: Then the king said to the woman, “I am going to ask you something; do not conceal it from me!” “Let my lord the king speak,” she replied.
translation: King i tokim meri, "Mi bai askim yu samting, yu no ken kailem long mi!" "Bihain bosi king i tok," meri i bekim.

original: So the king asked, “Is the hand of Joab behind all this?” The woman answered, “As surely as you live, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or to the left from anything that my lord the king says. Yes, your servant Joab is the one who gave me orders; he told your maidservant exactly what to say.
translation: King i askim, "Em Joab i bihain bilong ol dispela?" Meri i ansa, "Olsem yu stap, papa bilong mi king, nogat wan man i ken go raitsela na lefsela long eni tok husat yu king tok. Yes, servant bilong yu Joab em i givim mi tok; em i tokim hausmeri bilong yu olsem husat Hausmeri i mas tok.

original: Joab your servant has done this to bring about this change of affairs, but my lord has wisdom like the wisdom of the angel of God, to know everything that happens in the land.”
translation: Joab i servist bilong yu, em i mekim dispela long bringim bekim dispela kain sel bilong ol samting, tasol papa bilong yu i gat save olsem angel bilong God i gat, long save olgeta samting i kamap long graun.

original: Then the king said to Joab, “I hereby grant this request. Go, bring back the young man Absalom.”
translation: King i tokim Joab, “Mi givim dispela tokaut long dispela askim. Go, kam bek gen long yung man Absalom.”

original: Joab fell facedown in homage and blessed the king. “Today,” said Joab, “your servant knows that he has found favor with you, my lord the king, because the king has granted his request.”
translation: Joab i kirap daun long graon na mekim resis long king. “Tudei,” ol i tok, “wokman bilong yu, mi save nau olsem mi kisim bikpela hap wantaim yu, king, bikos yu givim askim bilong mi.”

original: So Joab got up, went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
translation: Na Joab i kam bek, i go long Gesuri, na i bringim Absalom i kam bek long Yerusalem.

original: But the king added, “He may return to his house, but he must not see my face.” So Absalom returned to his own house, but he did not see the king.
translation: King i mekim moa, “Em i go bak long haus bilong en, tasol em i no ken lukim pes bilong mi.” Na Absalom i go bak long haus bilong en, tasol em i no lukim king.

original: Now there was not a man in all Israel as handsome and highly praised as Absalom. From the sole of his foot to the top of his head, he did not have a single flaw.
translation: I no bin gat man olsem Absalom long Israel, husat i luk strong na i gat bikpela nem. From heel bilong foot long wei na go long top bilong hed, em i no gat birua, tasol em i stap strong na gutpela tru.

original: And when he cut the hair of his head—he shaved it every year because his hair got so heavy—he would weigh it out to be two hundred shekels, according to the royal standard.
translation: Na taim em i katim gras bilong hed blong en, em i shave olgeta yia bikos gras bilong en i kamap bikpela, em bai mesurim wai bilong en, na em i go stap long 200 sikel, strongpela loa long standart bilong king.

original: Three sons were born to Absalom, and a daughter named Tamar, who was a beautiful woman.
translation: Tripla man i kam long Absalom, na wanpela meri we em i kolim Tamar, em i meri stap strong na gutpela.

original: Now Absalom lived in Jerusalem two years without seeing the face of the king.
translation: Nau Absalom i stap long Jirosalem two yia bai hem i no lukim pes bilong king.

original: Then he sent for Joab to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come to him. So Absalom sent a second time, but Joab still would not come.
translation: Na Absalom i sendim Joab i kam bek long en, king, tasol Joab i no laik kam. Olsem Absalom i sendim gen taem narapela, tasol Joab i no kam bek gen.

original: Then Absalom said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire!” And Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
translation: Na Absalom i tokim servant bilong em, "Luksave, graun bilong Joab idae long graun bilong mi, na em i gat bari long hap. Go na rausim faia long em!" Na servant bilong Absalom i go na rausim faia long graun, na ol i barim graun bilong Joab.

original: Then Joab came to Absalom’s house and demanded, “Why did your servants set my field on fire?”
translation: Yoab i go kam long haus bilong Absalom na em i askim, "Ol servants bilong yu i setim gras bilong ples bilong mi i bung, long wanem?"

original: “Look,” said Absalom, “I sent for you and said, ‘Come here. I want to send you to the king to ask: Why have I come back from Geshur? It would be better for me if I were still there.’ So now, let me see the king’s face, and if there is iniquity in me, let him kill me.”
translation: “Lukim,” olsem Absalom, “Mi bin sendem yu kam na mi tokim yu, ‘Kam hia. Mi laik sendim yu go long king i askim: Bilong wanem mi kam bek gen long Geshur? Bai olsem nau i gutpela moa long me.” Sapos mi gat hevi i stap long me, em i kirapim mi. Nau, mi laik lukim pes bilong king, na sapos mi i gat hevi, bai king i killim mi.

original: So Joab went and told the king, and David summoned Absalom, who came to him and bowed facedown before him. Then the king kissed Absalom.
translation: Na Yoab i go tanim stori long king, na Daud i singautim Absalom, na Absalom i kam na i pakim hed i dai long graun bilong king. King i kisim Absalom olsem sahn bilong afeksin.

original: Some time later, Absalom provided for himself a chariot with horses and fifty men to run ahead of him.
translation: Oli bikos long taim igo pinis, Absalom i kukim ka kareta wantaim hores, na fifty man i ran i go bifo em.

original: He would get up early and stand beside the road leading to the city gate. Whenever anyone had a grievance to bring before the king for a decision, Absalom would call out and ask, “What city are you from?” And if he replied, “Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel,”
translation: Em bai kam daun erli na stanaside long rot i go long geit bilong taun. Wanem taim ol i gat samting nogut, ol bai bringim i go long king bilong king i makim desisan, Absalom bai singaut na askim, “Yu bilong wanem ples?” Na taim yu tok, “Mipela servan bilong mipela i kam long wanpela tribes bilong Israel,”

original: Absalom would say, “Look, your claims are good and right, but the king has no deputy to hear you.”
translation: Absalom bai tok, "Olkilok, tok-save bilong yu i gutpela na stret, tasol king i no gat kantri bilong en long harim yu."

original: And he would add, “If only someone would appoint me judge in the land, then everyone with a grievance or dispute could come to me, and I would give him justice.”
translation: Na em i mekim tok, "Mi laikim olsem sampela man i appointmentim mi olsem jaj long kantri, na olgeta man i gat samting nogut o faip inap kam long me bilong faizim rait, na mi bai givim rait long ol."

original: Also, when anyone approached to bow down to him, Absalom would reach out his hand, take hold of him, and kiss him.
translation: Na long taim ol i kam klostu longen, Absalom em i stretim han bilong en, kisim ol i holim, na givim ol sik.

original: Absalom did this to all the Israelites who came to the king for justice. In this way he stole the hearts of the men of Israel.
translation: Absalom i mekim dispela olsem long ol pipol bilong Israel ol i go long king bilong yumi na toktok long jastis. Na em i stilim het bilong ol man bilong Israel olsem.

original: After four years had passed, Absalom said to the king, “Please let me go to Hebron to fulfill a vow I have made to the LORD.
translation: Bihaenpela foa yia i go pinis, Absalom i tokim king, “Mipela yet long go long Hebon, olsem na bai mi ken fulfill promis bilong mi i mekim long GOD.”

original: For your servant made a vow while dwelling in Geshur of Aram, saying: ‘If indeed the LORD brings me back to Jerusalem, I will worship the LORD in Hebron.’”
translation: Wokman bilong yu makim promis wail em i stap long ples Geshur bilong Aram, olsem: 'Ip LORD i bringim yu bek long Yerusalem, yu servisim LORD long Hebron.'

original: “Go in peace,” said the king. So Absalom got up and went to Hebron.
translation: Ol ki bilong king i tokim, "Go long wei peis." Na Absalom i kirap na i go long Hebron.

original: Then Absalom sent spies throughout the tribes of Israel with this message: “When you hear the sound of the horn, you are to say, ‘Absalom reigns in Hebron!’”
translation: Na Absalom salim ol spies long olgeta hap bilong olpela trib na Israel wantaim mesaage ya: “Wanpela taim yu harim saund bilong horn, yu mas tok, 'Absalom i bos long Hebron!'”

original: Two hundred men from Jerusalem accompanied Absalom. They had been invited as guests and they went along innocently, for they knew nothing about the matter.
translation:
Tok Pisin:
Ol ples boi two hundred husat i kam long Jerusalem i go wail wantaim Absalom. Ol i bin invitim olsem gas na ol i go naik wail long wei, long biknem, ol i no save long dispela matemat.

original: While Absalom was offering the sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counselor, to come from his hometown of Giloh. So the conspiracy gained strength, and Absalom’s following kept increasing.
translation: Wail Absalom i bin givim sakrifis, em i sendim bos long Ahithophel, man bilong toksave bilong David, i kam bek long ples bilong em Giloh. Na kanu ol i harim strong, na ol i go bek gen long Absalom, na ol i folo im i stap.

original: Then a messenger came to David and reported, “The hearts of the men of Israel are with Absalom.”
translation: Wanpela ran i bring news i kam long Daud na i tokim em, “Haret bilong ol man bilong Israel i stap wantaim Absalom.”

original: And David said to all the servants with him in Jerusalem, “Arise and let us flee, or we will not escape from Absalom! We must leave quickly, or he will soon overtake us, heap disaster on us, and put the city to the sword.”
translation: Na Davide i tokim ol servant bilong em long Jerusalem olsem, "Kam na yumit yet, mipela mas ranawe, nogat narapela wei bai mipela inap savesim laip bilong mipela from Absalom! Mipela mas lusikik nau, or hem bai kisim bek mipela, bai bringim bikpela bagarap long mipela, na bai kilim ol pipol long siti wantaim sord."

original: The king’s servants replied, “Whatever our lord the king decides, we are your servants.”
translation: Servant bilong king i tokim, "Olgeta samting we lord king itok, mipela em servant bilong yu."

original: Then the king set out, and his entire household followed him. But he left behind ten concubines to take care of the palace.
translation: King i go bek, na ol famili bilong en i foloim em, tasol em i lusim behain ten meri pasal long mekim wara long haus bilong king.

original: So the king set out with all the people following him. He stopped at the last house,
translation: King i go bek, na ol pipol i foloem i go. Em i stop long hap haus bilong ol.

original: and all his servants marched past him—all the Cherethites and Pelethites, and six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath.
translation: Na ol servan bilong em, Cherethites na Pelethites olsem solja win bilong em, ol i go pasim em, na tu sis hunred Gittites long Gath olsem solja ibilong nesen arapela ol i bihainim em kam long Gath, ol i go pasim em.

original: Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why should you also go with us? Go back and stay with the new king, since you are both a foreigner and an exile from your homeland.
translation: Na king i tok olsem long Itai man Gati, "Yu go wantaim mipela, bilum yu? Yu go bek na stap wantaim nupela king, olsem na yu man i kam long narapela hap na yu i stap we, yu i man i kam long kantri birua, na yu i stap long kantri bilong yumi."

original: In fact, you arrived only yesterday; should I make you wander around with us today while I do not know where I am going? Go back and take your brothers with you. May the LORD show you loving devotion and faithfulness.”
translation: Yu kam bek gen istap asde, bai mipela mekim yu wakabaut wantaim mipela tude, while mi no save long we mi go? Go bak na kisim brata bilong yu na karim i go. Mipela hope LORD bai givim yu lav na katpela, olsem wankain bilong trut na strongpela harti.

original: But Ittai answered the king, “As surely as the LORD lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether it means life or death, there will your servant be!”
translation: Ittai i ansa long king, “Olsem LORD i stap, na olsem yu king yu stap, we bilong yu king i go, mi go tu, bai olgets laip o ba dae, servant bilong yu bai stap.”

original: “March on then,” said David to Ittai. So Ittai the Gittite marched past with all his men and all the little ones who were with him.
translation: “Go na forward,” olsem Daud i tokim Ittai. Na Ittai bilong Giti i kam pas, wantaim olgeta manmeri bilong en, na liklik manmeri ol i stap wantaim em.

original: Everyone in the countryside was weeping loudly as all the people passed by. And as the king crossed the Kidron Valley, all the people also passed toward the way of the wilderness.
translation: Ol pipol long bus bilong kantri ol i krai i go strong olsem ol i pas long bihain. Na king i go kilim Kidron Valley, na ol pipol i go i kam long rot bilong wilpela kantri.

original: Zadok was also there, and all the Levites with him were carrying the ark of the covenant of God. And they set down the ark of God, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until the people had passed out of the city.
translation: Na Zadok i stap tu, na ol Levait jengan em, ol i kisim bek arak bilong kaunsil bilong God. Na ol i let daun arak bilong God, na Abiathar i bringim sakris long taim ol pipel i pinis go na i kamaut long siti.

original: Then the king said to Zadok, “Return the ark of God to the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the LORD, He will bring me back and let me see both it and His dwelling place again.
translation: King i tokim Zadok, “Kisim bek ark bilong God i go bek long taun. If God i save olsem mi lukim favor long ai bilong LORD, em bai bringim mi bek na mi bai lukim gen ark bilong God na haus bilong spirit bilong em.

original: But if He should say, ‘I do not delight in you,’ then here I am; let Him do to me whatever seems good to Him.”
translation: Bai em i laik tok olsem, 'Mi no likim yu,' na mi stap hirere; em inap mekim gen long me olgeta samting em i tink i gut long en.

original: The king also said to Zadok the priest, “Are you not a seer? Return to the city in peace—you with your son Ahimaaz, and Abiathar with his son Jonathan.
translation: King i tokim Zadok biskop, “Yu no save man prophet? Yu go bek long town na stap long peis – yu wantaim pikinini bilong yu Ahimaaz, na Abiathar wantaim pikinini bilong em Jonathan.

original: See, I will wait at the fords of the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.”
translation: Mi bai wait long narapela hap bilong bus, na mi bai go long yu kam tok, na yumi ken tok ples long olgeta samting.

original: So Zadok and Abiathar returned the ark of God to Jerusalem and stayed there.
translation: Na Zadok na Abiathar i bringim bek ark bilong God long Jerusalem na ol i stap we.

original: But David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went up. His head was covered, and he was walking barefoot. And all the people with him covered their heads and went up, weeping as they went.
translation: Bare Davidson i go ap long Maunt Olives, nakat i cry, na i go ap. Hed bilong en i kisim hevi, kisim hed, na i wok bari fut. Na ol pipol i kam wantaim em, ol i kisim hevi, kisim hed bilong ol, na ol i go ap, nakat ol i cry, na ol i go ap.

original: Now someone told David: “Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.” So David pleaded, “O LORD, please turn the counsel of Ahithophel into foolishness!”
translation: Wanpela man i tokim Davide: “Ahithophel i kamap wantok long plan wantaim Absalom.” Na Davide i birua, “O Bikpela, yu bikim ol kaunsil bilong Ahithophel i kamap ol samting nogut na bilong ken!”

original: When David came to the summit, where he used to worship God, Hushai the Archite was there to meet him with his robe torn and dust on his head.
translation: Taim David kamap long mauntin top, we em i usim worship long God olgeta, Hushai Arcite i stap bek gen long meetim em, na em i gat sorere: laplap i pullum na dus i save stap long hed bilong en.

original: David said to him, “If you go on with me, you will be a burden to me.
translation: Daud i tokim em, "Yu kam na go wantaim mi, yu ken kam na wari long mi."

original: But you can thwart the counsel of Ahithophel for me if you return to the city and say to Absalom: ‘I will be your servant, my king; in the past I was your father’s servant, but now I will be your servant.’
translation: Bai yu ken bagarapim kaunsil bilong Ahithophel long me ifyu go bek long siti na tokim Absalom: 'Mi bai servit yu, king bilong mi; long taim bipo mi bin servit papa bilong yu, tasol nau mi bai servit yu.'

original: Will not Zadok and Abiathar the priests be there with you? Report to them everything you hear from the king’s palace.
translation: Zadok na Abiathar ol priest bai stap wantaim yu? Ripotim olgeta samting yu harim long haus bilong king.

original: Indeed, their two sons, Ahimaaz son of Zadok and Jonathan son of Abiathar, are there with them. Send them to me with everything you hear.”
translation: Em i triu, tupela pikinini bilong ol, Ahimaaz pikinini bilong Zadok na Jonatan pikinini bilong Abiatara, ol i stap wantaim ol. Senisim ol i kam long me wantaim ol samting yu harim.

original: So David’s friend Hushai arrived in Jerusalem just as Absalom was entering the city.
translation: Poroman bilong Dauid, Hushai, i kam long Yerusalemu wail tasol Absalom i go insait long siti.

original: When David had gone a little beyond the summit, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth was there to meet him. He had a pair of saddled donkeys loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred clusters of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a skin of wine.
translation: Taim Davide i go lil bit pasim hap bilong mauntin, Ziba wokman bilong Mefibosete em i stap waitim em. Em i kisim tupela donki i redi long ridim, i save karim ka, na i gat lof bilong bret two hundred, kalabasi raisin one hundred, ka bilong taim hot one hundred, na sking bilong wain.

original: “Why do you have these?” asked the king. Ziba replied, “The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride, the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat, and the wine is to refresh those who become exhausted in the wilderness.”
translation: King i askim, "Wai yus i gat dispela?" Ziba i tok, "Ol donki bilong ples bilong king olsem nau bai yusa long ridim, bret na fut bilong somer em i go long ol yangpela man bai kaikai, na wain em i go long mekim ol man husat i peni long bus long stap strong."

original: “Where is your master’s grandson?” asked the king. And Ziba answered, “Indeed, he is staying in Jerusalem, for he has said, ‘Today, the house of Israel will restore to me the kingdom of my grandfather.’”
translation: King i askim, "We bilong maus bilong papa blong yu i stap we?" Na Ziba i ansa, "Em i stap long Jerusalem, bikos em i tok, 'Tude, haus bilong Israel bai bringim bek gen kingdm bilong tumbuna bilong mi long mi.'"

original: So the king said to Ziba, “All that belongs to Mephibosheth is now yours!” “I humbly bow before you,” said Ziba. “May I find favor in your eyes, my lord the king!”
translation: King i tokim Ziba, "Olgeta samting bilong Mephiboset em nau bilong yu!" "Mi bagarap long yu," tok Ziba, "Papa king bilong mi, bai mi finisim gut long ai bilong yu!"

original: As King David approached Bahurim, a man from the family of the house of Saul was just coming out. His name was Shimei son of Gera, and as he approached, he kept yelling out curses.
translation: King Daoud i go klostu long Bahurim, man wanpela husat i kam long famili bilong haus bilong Saul em i kam aut. Nem bilong em Shimei son bilong Gera, na em i kam klostu, em i stap singsingaut ol kukai.

original: He threw stones at David and at all the servants of the king, though the troops and all the mighty men were on David’s right and left.
translation: Emi pilai ston long Dauid na long ol wokman bilong king, nogat ol soldia na ol man strongpela i stap long sait rait na lef bilong Dauid.

original: And as he yelled curses, Shimei said, “Get out, get out, you worthless man of bloodshed!
translation: Na em i kisim strongpela kukim ol i go we, Shimei i tok, “Go long, go long, yu man i no gat wari long en, man bilong shedim blod!

original: The LORD has paid you back for all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you have reigned, and the LORD has delivered the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. See, you have come to ruin because you are a man of bloodshed!”
translation: LORD i bin pekimpim yu bek long olgeta bled bilong haus bilong Saul, we yu bin bos long taim, na LORD i bin givim kingdom ikam long han bilong pikininiyu Absalom. Lukim, yu go daun long bagarap bikos yu em i man bilong shedim blod!

original: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head!”
translation: Na Abishai pikinini bilong Zeruiah i tokim king olsem, “Wai dispela dok i dai pinis i karim curses long bikman bilong mipela? Mipela lusim yumi go kisim hed bilong em!”

original: But the king replied, “What have I to do with you, O sons of Zeruiah? If he curses me because the LORD told him, ‘Curse David,’ who can ask, ‘Why did you do this?’”
translation: King i tok bek, “Wanem samting yu mekim wantaim mi, ol pikinini bilong Zeruiah? I sori long olsem em i krosim mi bikos Bikpela i tokim em, ‘Davi i kros,’ husait bai askim, ‘Bikos wanem yu mekim olsem?’”

original: Then David said to Abishai and to all his servants, “Behold, my own son, my own flesh and blood, seeks my life. How much more, then, this Benjamite! Leave him alone and let him curse me, for the LORD has told him so.
translation: Na Davide i tokim Abisai na ol seranan bilong em, "Pikinini bilong mi, hed bilong mi, i kam bek long mekim olsem, i lukim lif bilong mi. Olsem na, Man bilong Benjimin dispela, Lusim em, lego em i cursim mi, wantaim olgetting LORD i tokim em olsem.

original: Perhaps the LORD will see my affliction and repay me with good for the cursing I receive today.”
translation: Mipela katol bikpela i lukim sik mama bilong mi, na bai mipela bikpela i bekim mi gutpela long olsem nau mipela i kros.

original: So David and his men proceeded along the road as Shimei went along the ridge of the hill opposite him. As Shimei went, he yelled curses, threw stones, and flung dust at David.
translation: Na David wantaim ol man bilong en i go long rot, Shimei i wokabaut long hap bilong hil klostu long en. Shimei i go, ol i kirapim kakai i no gat senis, ol i tromoi ston, na ol i potala dus long David.

original: Finally, the king and all the people with him arrived, exhausted. And there he refreshed himself.
translation: Nau king na ol pipol we i go wantaim em, ol i kamap, ol i bin tired longlong. Na bungim bel bilong en i kamap, em i tek kaikai tasol, na bungim bel.

original: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
translation: Na Absalom na ol man meri bilong Isrel i kam long Jerusalem, na Ahithophel i stap wantaim em.

original: And David’s friend Hushai the Archite went to Absalom and said to him, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
translation: Na Husai Arcite, poroman bilong Davide, i go kam long Absalom na i tokim em: “King i stap oltaim! King i stap oltaim!”

original: “Is this the loyalty you show your friend?” Absalom replied. “Why did you not go with your friend?”
translation: Em i loyalti bilong yu long narapela man? Absalom i tok, "Bai yu no go wantaim narapela man?"

original: “Not at all,” Hushai answered. “For the one chosen by the LORD, by the people, and by all the men of Israel—his I will be, and with him I will remain.
translation: “Nogat tasol,” Hushai i tokim. “Bilong wanpela i pikinim LONG LORD bilong yumiyami, bilong ol piple, na bilong olgeta manmeri bilong Israel – em bai mi stap wantaim em, na bai mi stap.”

original: Furthermore, whom should I serve if not the son? As I served in your father’s presence, so also I will serve in yours.”
translation: Husat bai mi servim, nogat pikinini? Olsem nau mi servim long taim bilong papa bilong yu, olsem tasol bai mi servim long taim bilong yu.

original: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give me counsel. What should we do?”
translation: Na Absalom i tokim Ahitofel, “Givim mi kaunsil. Bai yumi mekim wanem?”

original: Ahithophel replied, “Sleep with your father’s concubines, whom he has left to keep the palace. When all Israel hears that you have become a stench to your father, then the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened.”
translation: Ahithophel i tokim bek, “Yu slip wantaim ol meri bilong papa yu, ol i stap kiim haus bilong chief. Na taim ol Israel hariam, ol bai save long dispela: yu kamap narapela smel i no good long papa yu, na bai ol han bilong ol man i stap wantaim yu i strong.”

original: So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he slept with his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.
translation: Ol i planim wanpela tent long hap tumuna bilong Absalom, na em i slip wantaim meri bilong servis bilong papa bilong em long ai bilong olgeta Israel.

original: Now in those days the advice of Ahithophel was like the consultation of the word of God. Such was the regard that both David and Absalom had for Ahithophel’s advice.
translation: Long long taim bifo, kaunsil bilong Ahitofel i olsem tok bilong God em i tok, na respek we i go long Dauid na Absalom i stap strong long en.

original: Furthermore, Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men and set out tonight in pursuit of David.
translation: Na Ahitofel i tokim Absalom olsem, "Mipela bai mi pilim twelv tasin man, na mipela tupela yumi go bek long nait, go pasim David.

original: I will attack him while he is weak and weary; I will throw him into a panic, and all the people with him will flee; I will strike down only the king
translation: Bai mi go bekim em wail em i no inap na i peni, bai mi mekim em iet long ples bilong en, ol man meri i kam wantaim em bai ranawe, bai mi kilim king tasol.

original: and bring all the people back to you as a bride returning to her husband. You seek the life of only one man; then all the people will be at peace.”
translation: Na bingim ol pipol i go bek gen olsem meri i kam bek long husban bilong en. Yupela luk save long laip bilong wanpela man tasol, na bai ol pipol oli stap gut na is.

original: This proposal seemed good to Absalom and all the elders of Israel.
translation: Dispela toksave i luk gut long Absalom na ol big man bilong Israel.

original: Then Absalom said, “Summon Hushai the Archite as well, and let us hear what he too has to say.”
translation: Na Absalom i tok, "Kisim Hushai bilong Archite tu, na mipela harim wanem samting em i mas tok."

original: So Hushai came to Absalom, who told him, “Ahithophel has spoken this proposal. Should we carry it out? If not, what do you say?”
translation: Husaai i kam long Absalom, na Absalom i tokim em, "Ahitofel i givim dispela propozal. Yumi mas wokim olsem? Sapos nogat, yu tok olsem wanem?"

original: Hushai replied, “This time the advice of Ahithophel is not sound.”
translation: Hushai i tokim, “Taim bilong dispela kaunsil bilong Ahithophel i no gut.”

original: He continued, “You know your father and his men. They are mighty men, and as fierce as a wild bear robbed of her cubs. Moreover, your father is a man of war who will not spend the night with the troops.
translation: Em i go bek long stori, “Yupela save papa bilong yupela na ol man bilong en. Ol i strongpela man, na ol i strongpela olsem bear we ibin lusim pipel bilong en. Papa bilong yu em i man bilong pai we no save slip long nait wantaim ol solder.

original: Surely by now he is hiding in a cave or some other location. If some of your troops fall first, whoever hears of it will say, ‘There has been a slaughter among the troops who follow Absalom.’
translation: Nau olsem em i hidim i go long hole o ples narakai. I gat bikpela posibol ol soljata bung i go daun first, na husat i harim tok bilong dispela, ol bai tok, 'I gat bikpela kileng long ol soljata i stap wantaim Absalom.'

original: Then even the most valiant soldier with the heart of a lion will melt with fear, because all Israel knows that your father is a mighty man who has valiant men with him.
translation: Na solja strongpela bai i kukim na ikam long bikmus, wantaim het bilong lion, bikos ol Israel i save olsem papa bilong yu em i man strongpela i gat power, na i gat ol solja strongpela wantaim em.

original: Instead, I advise that all Israel from Dan to Beersheba—a multitude like the sand on the seashore—be gathered to you, and that you yourself lead them into battle.
translation: Mi givim advisi olsem, husat i kam long Isrel, stat long Dan go kas long Beersheba—ol i liklik samting olsem san long solwara—ol i kam long yu, na yu i lidim ol long faet.

original: Then we will attack David wherever we find him, and we will descend on him like dew on the ground. And of all the men with him, not even one will remain.
translation: Em bai yumit yet, yumi go harim Dauid weh yumi finim em, na kamdaun i kam stap long em olsem dew long graun, na ol man husat i stap wantaim em, maski wan tasol i no inap remain.

original: If he retreats to a city, all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it down to the valley until not even a pebble can be found.”
translation: Em i go bek long wanpela taun, Ol Israel olgeta bai bringim rop long taun, na mipela bai kisim i daun long bele, na nogat even smol ston i stap.

original: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai the Archite is better than that of Ahithophel.” For the LORD had purposed to thwart the good counsel of Ahithophel in order to bring disaster on Absalom.
translation: Na Absalom na ol manmeri bilong Israel i tok olsem, "Tok bilong Hushai Arcite i gutpela moa long tok bilong Ahithophel." Bikos LORD i bin laikim bikim plan bilong Ahithophel i no inap, olsem bai bringim hevi i kam long Absalom.

original: So Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, “This is what Ahithophel has advised Absalom and the elders of Israel, and this is what I have advised.
translation: Husaai i tokim Zadok na Abiatar, ol padi, “Ahitofel i givim dispela kain advais long Absalom na lo ol bikpela man bilong Israel, na mi givim dispela kain advais.”

original: Now send quickly and tell David, ‘Do not spend the night at the fords of the wilderness, but be sure to cross over. Otherwise the king and all the people with him will be swallowed up.’”
translation: Nau sikim kvik na tokim Davide, ‘No nap long nait long wara bilong bus, yu mas crossim i go.’ Inap king na ol pipol wantaim em bai kaikai i kam bek.

original: Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En-rogel, where a servant girl would come and pass along information to them. They in turn would go and inform King David, for they dared not be seen entering the city.
translation: Nau Jonathan na Ahimaaz i stap long En-rogel, wane meri servist i kam na givim news i go long ol. Ol bihaenim go tokim King David, bikos ol i no ken go insait long taun, ol i bin fear tumas long kam insait.
